Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Extended depth imaging with optical coherence tomography (OCT)
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is in the development of new optical imaging techniques for evaluating the health of skin, teeth and gums. Optical imaging uses light instead of X-rays to produce detailed images of tissues. It has not yet been widely applied for dental and dermatology applications because the light does not penetrate deeply enough into tissues to be useful, and these devices are prohibitively expensive to manufacture. This project will develop a a new imaging scheme that allows deeper penetration into tissues, providing more useful diagnostic information; and with current 3D manufacturing techniques, it could cost roughly ten times less than the current alternatives. This technology will enable new safe, affordable imaging processes.<br/><br/>This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project advances translation of a novel optical technique, dual axis deep imaging optical coherence tomography (OCT), for clinical imaging of skin and teeth. Translation of OCT is advanced for retinal imaging but has not enjoyed the same success in other applications. This project will create new instruments for dentistry and dermatology by demonstrating: 1) how dual axis OCT can penetrate more deeply in biological tissues using instruments designed for each application; and 2) the economic feasibility using 3D manufacturing and system design.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this project we continued the development of the dual-axis deep imaging optical coherence tomography imaging system (DA-OCT). The DA-OCT was integrated with the ultrasound transducer from MicroElastic's Shear Wave Elasticity Imaging system to create a novel optical coherence elastography (OCE) system. Using DA-OCT for detection of the shearwave enable higher resolution observation with no interference between the ultrasound excitation and the DA-OCT observation.

We built a prototype system and did initial testing on skin phantoms. An in vivo proof of principle trial was done on skin on four human volunteers. The system was able to differentiate the elasticity of stretched skin from skin at rest.

We then developed an oral cavity scanner for the DA-OCT system. This is a side viewing probe that is approximately 10 cm long and 6 mm in diameter. It can be used to image the teeth and oral cavity tissue in vivo. Testing was done on human skin and human teeth from several volunteers.

The DA-OCT did increase the imaging depth in highly scattering samples, but not as much as expected. In an effort to improve imaging depth, we designed and built a version of the system operating at 1580 nm. However, this version did not improve the imaging depth over the 1310 nm version. 

The development from this project was translated into our current product offerings as the 1310 nm, the OQ Stratascope. We are continuing development of additional products in deep-imaging dual axis OCT.


Last Modified: 12/23/2022
Modified by: William Brown
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: During this project we continued the development of the dual-axis deep imaging optical coherence tomography imaging system (DA-OCT). The DA-OCT was integrated with the ultrasound transducer from MicroElastic's Shear Wave Elasticity Imaging system to create a novel optical coherence elastography (OCE) system. Using DA-OCT for detection of the shearwave enable higher resolution observation with no interference between the ultrasound excitation and the DA-OCT observation. We built a prototype system and did initial testing on skin phantoms. An in vivo proof of principle trial was done on skin on four human volunteers. The system was able to differentiate the elasticity of stretched skin from skin at rest. We then developed an oral cavity scanner for the DA-OCT system. This is a side viewing probe that is approximately 10 cm long and 6 mm in diameter. It can be used to image the teeth and oral cavity tissue in vivo. Testing was done on human skin and human teeth from several volunteers. The DA-OCT did increase the imaging depth in highly scattering samples, but not as much as expected. In an effort to improve imaging depth, we designed and built a version of the system operating at 1580 nm. However, this version did not improve the imaging depth over the 1310 nm version. The development from this project was translated into our current product offerings as the 1310 nm, the OQ Stratascope. We are continuing development of additional products in deep-imaging dual axis OCT. Last Modified: 12/23/2022 Submitted by: William Brown
